Award.AwardTitle: New Methods of Fault Simulation and Location for Smart Grids Based on Synchronized Measurements

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Objectives and Approaches

The objective of this research is to develop an accurate and computationally efficient technique in order to locate and identify faults in power systems using synchronized measurements. The approach is to capture the arrival times of the fault-initiated traveling waves using a few synchronized sensors and triangulating the location of the fault based on the recorded arrival times of these waves.

Intellectual Merit

The intellectual merit of the proposal is the utilization of synchronized voltage samples recorded by sparsely placed sensors in order to accurately determine the location of faults in power systems. Current utilization of these sensors is confined to synchronized phasors. This project will utilize for the first time the point-on-wave samples which are synchronized throughout the entire power system. This will be transformative leading to new applications that can exploit information related to traveling waves on power lines.

Broader Impacts

This project will expand the application areas for synchronized measurements which are
rapidly being deployed in increasing numbers in smart grids. This will have an impact on the new investments on system protection and quality of service for all major utilities in the country. Two graduate students will be trained in the area of electric grids, crucial
to designing nation's future energy system. Furthermore, project's results will be incorporated into the curriculum through lab exercises. Also, students from underrepresented groups will be targeted through the university's STEMteams, NUPrime (multi-cultural engineering) and WIE (women in engineering) programs and supported by REU supplements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Designing and implementing protection, control as well as fault location functions require accurate transient simulation tools that can account for frequency dependency of network parameters, in particular those of the untransposed transmission lines and cables.  It is well known that time domain simulation methods have been less than accurate in accounting for the frequency dependencies of line parameters due to the constant modal transformation matrix used at each time step of simulations. This project addresses this deficiency by creating a framework for using customized subband-domain representations of transient waveforms, to model and simulate transients in dispersive systems such as meshed power grids. These results are used to develop a subband-domain electromagnetic transient simulation program (SD-EMTP) capable of accurately simulating fast transients properly accounting for frequency dependencies in network parameters.   The project also develops a new fault location method based on the equivalence between fault current drawn at a point along a line section and a pair of virtual superimposed injections at the terminals of the faulted line.  This approach relies on sparsely distributed synchronized voltage measurements before and after the fault and has modest bandwidth requirements. So, it can be applied to systems which are monitored by digital fault recorders or similar devices.   In addition to these technical achievements, the project’s results are expected to have some broader impacts on the society.  The developed methodologies will help incorporation of synchronized measurement technologies into power grids by providing practical and effective applications for their utilization.  Such integration is also expected to facilitate the use and management of renewable energy sources which are typically connected at low voltage grids where protection, control and fault location issues are more challenging.  Society will benefit from increased integration of renewable sources due to reduced pollution and energy savings.  It is noted that two students were trained in the area of power grids during the course of the project and they will be contributing to designing nation's future energy system. They have also published their work, thus contributed to the dissemination of useful technical knowledge.
